app.note: The t and h are joined in a ligature, and not written as simple akṣara th.
The (single!) circular trace between mvai and ya is probably accidental.
Cf. Air Baraṅan in Mantyasih inscriptions.
Read saparānya? The apparent cecak can be considered accidental. Cf. 59XXXVII mangilala drabya haji saparānya sadeçānya; OJODDV p. 59 saparanya.
Nakada mistakenly places the first syllable in the lacuna at the end of 1r7.
The lu is still discernible, and the space before it is well preserved, without showing any trace of a punctuation sign.
Perhaps read ṇḍauka? How precisely it is spelled remains unclear, but the intended toponym must be lupaṇḍak.

app.lem: si bunā, kalima si sruka, juru muR̥ṁ si klat·, sal· si kulinā
app.note: Everything that follows on this line after si bunā is omitted by Nakada (perhaps due to eye-skip to kalima in the next line).
It is likely that the plate originally read tāmraprasasti.
Nakada reports the reading . by Oemar for the same sign.

div.p: Hail! Elapsed Śaka year 728, month of Māgha, ninth of the waxing fortnight, Hariyaṅ, Umanis, Thursday. At that time Rakai Patapān Pu Manuku demarcated the land of Muṇḍuan and of Haji Huma, given as apanage to his servant Patoran. His royal corvée will be to guard the goats … the extent of the kuramvit of the holy insignia of Patapān down to the future’s future. The name is ‘The place of guarding of the goats by the apanage holder’. And so he made a dwelling at the vindu-vindus of the land. That is the reason that the dwelling is called ‘Vala Vindu’. Thereupon he was given the grant that the land may not be entered by the Er Baraṅan, and by all kinds of collectors … of buying and selling. Especially those who have a record of good or bad deeds, may the land not be entered by them. Thus was the grant of Raka Patapān Pu Manuku to his servant Patoran, and to all who reside in Vala Vindu. If there are who disturb this grant, their reward into the future’s future is that of the five great sins

The minister of Patapān at that time was the Kayumvuṅan called Rupyan; the Mantyasih, servant of the Rakai Patapān, was the one named Palindua; the Partaya was the one named Pagəh. All of them were given gifts of 1 dhāraṇa of silver, 1 yugala of cloth per person. For the Lupaṇḍak(s) of the Er Baraṅan: 8 māṣas of gold; 1 yugala of cloth per person. For the Wahuta Pətir and the Paṇḍakyan: 1 dhāraṇa of silver, 1 yugala of cloth per person. For the 4 pituṅtuṅs of the two villages, 4 māṣas of silver per person. The headman of Muṇḍuan named Bunā, the kalima named Sruka, the juru murəṅ named Klat, the … named Kulinā, the daṇḍa murəṅ named Andhani, the kaṇḍaṅan lavəs named Tija; the kalima of Haji Huma named Sruva, the juru siniṅ, parvuvus, the maṇḍər paraṅ named Guṇī: all of them they were given gifts in silver and cloth in accordance with their efforts. Minaṅa, the scribe of Rakai Patapān who wrote the … copper-decree, was given 8 māṣa of silver, 1 yugala of cloth.

The noun kuramwit must lay at the basis of the place name Kuramwitan attested in a few inscriptions; perhaps it is derived from an (unattested) base kamwit. Connection with keramat? There is a word kerambit meaning ‘small sickle’ in Malay.
On the toponyms figuring here, see 151-160.

Note that the two kalimas bear the names Sruka and Sruva, which are evidently (derived from) the Sanskrit words for two types of ritual spoons, the sruk and the sruva. This parallelism of names suggests a strong connection of some sort between the two persons in question, despite their affiliation with two different villages.
